occurrences.line_text: That wont in charet chace the foming Bore;
Both charet swift and huntsman ouercast.
Clymbe to her charet, all with flowers spred;
His whirling charet, for exceeding feare:
Arose, she bad her charet to be brought,
Drew the smooth charet of sad Cymoent;
They easily vnto her charet beare:
With burning charet wheeles it nigh to smite:
His charet swift in haste he thither steard,
Remouing her, into his charet brought,
And tyde behind his charet, to aggrate
Who bold to guide the charet of the Sunne,
That his swift charet might haue passage wyde,
One in a charet of straunge furniment,
The charet decked was in wondrous wize,
In her great iron charet wonts to ride,
Mounted in Phoebus charet fierie bright,
If he too rashly to his charet drew,
The yron charet, and the wheeles did teare,
Bad eke attonce their charets to be sought;
Of the Rich strond, their charets they forlore,
He at his first incomming, charg'd his spere
He at his entrance charg'd his powrefull speare
Charg'd with his speare and mortally did wound,
Yet charge of them was to a Porter hight
Forthwith he gaue in charge vnto his Squire,
For he had charge my discipline to frame,
To whom the carefull charge of him she gaue,
Of all the house had charge and gouernement,
The fift had charge sicke persons to attend,
The sixt had charge of them now being dead,
Had charge the tender Orphans of the dead
The charge thereof vnto a couetous Spright
The charge, which God doth vnto me arret,
At last him turning to his charge behight,
So both attonce him charge on either side,
They gaue fresh charge, their forces gan to faile,
They all that charge did feruently apply,
That liues, pertaines in charge particulare,
But dare thou not, I charge, in any cace,
It forth she cald, and gaue it streight in charge,
As her Creatresse had in charge to her ordained.
And hath the charge of Neptunes mightie heard;
With speedie course, as bent to charge them new.
That to her Dwarfe, which had me in his charge,
Vnto whose trust the charge thereof was lent:
Which hath in charge the ingate of the yeare:
Which haue the sea in charge to them assinde,
But then he fear'd his mothers former charge
The charge of Iustice giuen was in trust,
Him charge with guilt, but rather doe quite clame:
For his sicke charge some harbour there to seeke;
Of his young charge, whereof he skilled nought:
In that good Hermits charge, whom he did pray
They left her so, in charge of one the best
In which him selfe was charged heauily
Foure charged two, and two surcharged one;
And lastly Iustice charged her with breach of lawes.
And there with guiltie bloudshed charged ryfe:
And fiercely charged them with all his force;
And charged him so fierce and furiously,
Shall chargefull be, or chaunge to you at all;
And tend our charges with obeisance meeke:
And charging him a fresh thus felly him bespake.
And fiercely charging him with all his might,
From fiery wheeles of his faire chariot
But faire Charissa to a louely fere
The deare Charissa where is she become?
By this Charissa, late in child-bed brought,
Albe Charissa were their chiefest founderesse.
And godly worke of Almes and charitee
And welcomde more for feare, then charitee;
Charmd or enchaunted (answerd he then ferce)
With Centaures bloud, and bloudie verses charm'd,
With cup thus charmd, him parting she deceiu'd;
The whiles with a loue lay she thus him sweetly charm'd.
And eue[r]more with mighty spels them charmd,
Charm'd those wild-beasts, that rag'd with furie mad.
Had not that charme from thee forwarned it:
By subtilty, nor slight, nor might, nor mighty charme.
The charme fulfild, dead suddenly he downe did sincke.
Or that the charme and venim, which they druncke,
Does charme her louers, and the feeble sprightes
The art of mightie words, that men can charme;
That well could charme his tongue, and time his speach
Gan mutter close a certaine secret charme,
His fair enchaunted steed, and eke his charmed launce.
Yea but (quoth she) he beares a charmed shield,
Couerd with charmed cloud from vew of day,
But God you neuer let his charmed speeches heare.
As he were charmed with inchaunted rimes,
And broke his staffe, with which he charmed semblants sly.
That doth the charmed Snake in slomber lay:
Glauncing vnwares in charmed looking glas,
He seekes out mighty charmes, to trouble sleepy mindes
Who all this while with charmes and hidden artes,
My bodie all, through charmes and magicke might,
In charmes and magicke to haue wondrous might,
If either salues, or oyles, or herbes, or charmes
Which after charmes and some enchauntments said,
Vnto thy bounteous baytes, and pleasing charmes,
That weenest words or charmes may force withstond:
His mighty staffe, that could all charmes defeat:
Her mighty charmes, her furious louing fit,
No idle charmes so lightly may remoue,
Nor herbes, nor charmes, nor counsell, that is chiefe
His maker with her charmes had framed him so well.
That with thy charmes the sharpest sight doest bind,
Amoret, through charmes decayd.
Cald by strong charmes out of eternall night,
For to efforce, when charmes had closed it afore.
Neither of idle shewes, nor of false charmes aghast.
A thousand charmes he formerly did proue;
Yet thousand charmes could not her stedfast heart remoue.
Those cursed leaues, his charmes backe to reuerse;
And more emboldned by the wicked charmes,
Charmes to the birds full many a pleasant lay,
With herbs, with charms, with cou[n]sell, & with teares,
But tears, nor charms, nor herbs, nor counsell might
Nor powr of charms, which she against him wrought,
And mounting straight vpon a charret hye,
Oft drew the Prince vnto his charret nigh,
His charret wheeles about him whirled round,
The Churne, and Charwell, two small streames, which   pained
And chase the saluage beast with busie payne,
From heauen high to chase the chearelesse darke,
From chase of greater beasts, whose brutish pryde
And chase away this too long lingring night,
Chase her away, from whence she came, to hell.
From her high spirit chase imperious feare,
Or any of the Thracian Nimphes in saluage chase.
In saluage chase, to rest as seem'd her meet.
They being chased, that did others chase.
And through the world incessantly doe chase,
That first vnto his hand in chase did happen neare.
Met him in chase, but he it challenge would,
And both as swift on foot, as chased Stags;
Then of wilde beastes if she had chased beene:
But beaten were, and chased all about.
They being chased, that did others chase.
And for what cause they chased so that Mayd.
Corflambo chaseth Placidas,
With dread whereof his chasing steedes aghast,
Chasing, and laying on them heauy lode,
Of a rude rout him chasing to and fro,
Chasing the gentle Calepine around,
Her chast hart had subdewd, to learne Dame pleasures toy.
Of her chast person, and a faithfull mate
Was quite dismembred, and his members chast
The eldest two most sober, chast, and wise,
As hell she hated, chast in worke and will;
And pyn'd his flesh, to keepe his body low and chast.
As a chast Virgin, that wronged beene:
For it is chast and pure, as purest snow,
And be for all chast Dames an endlesse moniment.
And beareth fruit of honour and all chast desire.
In all chast vertue, and true bounti-hed
But did abide for euer chast and sound.
For he the powre of chast hands might not beare,
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
In whose chast breast all bountie naturall,
And wondrous chast of life, yet lou'd of Knights & Lords.
That girdle gaue the vertue of chast loue,
Whose bodies chast, when euer in his powre
So chast and loyall liu'd, but she would striue
But on chast vertue grounded their desire,
That had despisde so chast and faire a dame,
Vnlesse that she were continent and chast,
Did the most chast Penelope possesse,
With all their powre, and her full fiercely chast
Did win the shore, whence he them chast away,
And chaste so fiercely after fearfull flight,
Through goodly temperance, and affection chaste,
And chaste desires do nourish in your mind,
But the chaste damzell, that had neuer priefe
Of her chaste bodie, nor with commune food,
And Lodestarre of all chaste affectione,
But she, or such as she, that is so chaste a wight.
Seeking to match the chaste with th'vnchaste Ladies traine.
Speedy Hippothoe, and chaste Actea,
But chaste him still, for all his Ladies cry;
My chaster Muse for shame doth blush to write;
To be the chastest flowre, that ay did spring
And win rich spoile of ransackt chastetee.
In th'one her rule, in th'other her rare chastitee.
That all the gifts of grace and chastitee
Full little weened I, that chastitee
Shall be t'aduance thy goodly chastitee,
Of chastitie and honour virginall:
She is the flowre of grace and chastitie,
As for pure chastitie and vertue rare,
In stedfast chastitie and vertue rare,
Of chastitie, none liuing may compaire:
Then losse of chastitie, or chaunge of loue:
In simple truth and blamelesse chastitie,
That was the flowre of faith and chastity;
It falles me here to write of Chastity,
Of chastity and vertue virginall,
In so great prayse of stedfast chastity,
That chastity did for it selfe embrace,
And soueraine fauour towards chastity,
But Britomart the flowre of chastity;
They tied were to stedfast chastity,
Firme Chastity, that spight ne blemish dare;
And burnt his beastly hart t'efforce her chastitye.
Would her haue chastiz'd with his yron flaile,
Threatning to chastize me, as doth t'a chyld pertaine.
Chattring their yron teeth, and staring wide
Dan Chaucer, well of English vndefyled,
But chaufd and fom'd, with courage fierce and sterne,
And swat, and chauf'd, and proued euery way:
To rub her temples, and to chaufe her chin,
With cruell chaufe their courages they whet,
Nor where it light, but gan to chaufe and sweat,
Eftsoones he perced through his chaufed chest
After long search and chauff, he turned backe
That in his chauffe he digs the trampled ground,
When his hot ryder spurd his chauffed side;
As chauffed Bore his bristles doth vpreare,
Who seeming sorely chauffed at his band,
Sore chauffed at my stay in such a cace,
And chauffed inly, seeing now no more
Chaufing and foming choler each against his fo.
And chauft, that any on his backe should sit;
A while she walkt, and chauft; a while she threw
He chauft, he grieu'd, he fretted, and he sigh't,
The chaulky Kenet, and the Thetis gray,
Much seemed he to mone her haplesse chaunce,
Did loose his vele by chaunce, and open flew:
Whose like infirmitie like chaunce may beare:
It chaunst (eternall God that chaunce did guide)
Great cause, I weene, you guided, or some vncouth chaunce.
Trompart forth stept, to stay the mortall chaunce,
Least worse betide thee by some later chaunce.
Or bide the chaunce at thine owne ieoperdie.
To threat to him, that minds his chaunce t'abye?
One cursed creature, he by chaunce espide,
The Prince by chaunce did on a Lady light,
Into this land by chaunce haue driuen bene,
For who can shun the chaunce, that dest'ny doth ordaine?
If chaunce I him encounter parauaunt;
Did chaunce to still into her wearie spright,
As he by chaunce did wander that same way,
Whose chaunce it was, that soone he did repent,
Exceeding mone, and curst that cruell chaunce,
Whom I in countrey cottage found by chaunce;
There them by chaunce encountred on the way
They sate to meat, and Satyrane his chaunce
Rather let try extremities of chaunce,
Much was he grieued with that gracelesse chaunce,
Like as a Lion that by chaunce doth fall
Where, as he to and fro by chaunce did trace,
All change is perillous, and all chaunce vnsound.
Where I by chaunce then wandring on the shore,
By chaunce beheld, he left the bloudy slaughter,
To weather his brode sailes, by chaunce hath spide
And to vpbrayd that chaunce, which him misfell,
Hauing by chaunce espide aduantage neare,
Whenas by chaunce he met vppon a day
When as by chaunce a comely Squire he found,
Hauing by chaunce a close aduantage vew'd,
Had not a wondrous chaunce his reskue wrought,
Or by some deadly chaunce be done to pine,
Arriuing there, as did by chaunce befall,
And both combynd, what euer chaunce were blowne,
Sir Calepine by chaunce, more then by choyce,
This fatall chaunce, this dolefull accident,
At last it chaunced this proud Sarazin
Me chaunced of a knight encountred bee,
At last she chaunced by good hap to meet
In which him chaunced false Duessa meete,
And by the way he chaunced to espy
There chaunced to the Princes hand to rize,
A knight that way there chaunced to repaire;
But chaunced on a craggy cliff to light;
Till that ere long they chaunced to espie
But Glauce, seeing all that chaunced there,
Amongst the rest she chaunced there to see
That had he chaunced not his shield to reare,
Such chaunces oft exceed all humaine thought:
That worldly chaunces doe amongst them cast,
Such men do Chaungelings call, so chaungd by Faeries theft.
He chaungd his minde from one to other ill:
But that too oft she chaung'd her natiue hew:
And chaungd her weary side, the better ease to take.
She thought, but chaung'd from one to other feare;
Him selfe he chaung'd faire Danaï¿½ to vew,
And chaung'd at pleasure for those impes of thine.
And friends profest are chaungd to foemen fell:
His Lyons skin chaungd to a pall of gold,
Into a bird it chaung'd, and from him past,
So wondrously now chaung'd, from that she was afore.
For trumpets sterne to chaunge mine Oaten reeds,
With chaunge of cheare the seeming simple maid
We may not chaunge (quoth he) this euil plight,
In hart, and chaunge in that great mothers face:
With chaunge of feare, to see the Lyon looke so grim.
And chaunge of hew great passion did bewray;
But she no whit did chaunge her constant mood:
Confest, how Philemon her wrought to chaunge her weede.
To chaunge thy will, and set Occasion free,
Can chaunge my cheare, or make me euer mourne;
Auise thee well, and chaunge thy wilfull mood,
To chaunge loue causelesse is reproch to warlike knight.
Which chaunge of colour did perforce vnfold,
To chaunge my liefe, and loue another Dame,
Ne list me chaunge; she th'Errant Damzell hight,
To Maridunum, that is now by chaunge
And feed her fancy with delightfull chaunge:
Sith late mischaunce had her compeld to chaunge
Then losse of chastitie, or chaunge of loue:
Gan greatly chaunge, and seem'd dismayd to bee;
Then Paridell began to chaunge his theme,
Inconstant Chaunge, and false Disloyaltie,
That sight of such a chaunge her much dismayd.
She was become, by chaunge of her estate,
His chaunge of cheere, that anguish did bewray,
Not all the gods can chaunge, nor Ioue him self can free.
Fearlesse of fortunes chaunge or enuies dread,
For any death to chaunge life though most bad:
But hauing chosen, now he might not chaunge.
As sundry chaunge her seemed best to ease.
At such a chaunge, and ioyed to behold
Nether of enuy, nor of chaunge afeard,
Shall chargefull be, or chaunge to you at all;
To chaunge the manner of his loftie looke;
His chaunged powres at first them selues not felt,
At last when they had markt the chaunged skyes,
Chaunged thy liuely cheare, and liuing made thee dead?
All suddeinly abasht she chaunged hew,
But chaunged is, and often altred to and fro.
The substance is not chaunged, nor altered,
Transformed oft, and chaunged diuerslie:
Ne chaunged was into a starre in sky:
As all things else in time are chaunged quight.
Or sent into the chaungefull world againe,
Such men do Chaungelings call, so chaungd by Faeries theft.
The diuelish hag by chaunges of my cheare
The mightie ones, affrayd of euery chaunges dread.
That holds the world in his still chaunging state,
Oft chaunging sides, and oft new place electing,
Subiect to fortunes chance, still chaunging new;
His Ladie seeing all, that chaunst, from farre
At length they chaunst to meet vpon the way
At last him chaunst to meete vpon the way
I chaunst to see her in her proper hew,
At last the Paynim chaunst to cast his eye,
Vnlesse she chaunst their stubborne mouths to twitch;
A Satyre chaunst her wandring for to find,
And chaunst vnwares to meet him in the way,
Then gan the Pilgrim thus, I chaunst this day,
I lately chaunst (Would I had neuer chaunst)
I lately chaunst (Would I had neuer chaunst)
It chaunst (eternall God that chaunce did guide)
Or rather would, O would it so had chaunst,
When ill is chaunst, but doth the ill increase,
At last as chaunst them by a forest side
Dan Faunus chaunst to meet her by the way,
And oft himselfe he chaunst to hurt vnwares,
Sir Guyon chaunst eke on another booke,
To fill his hellish gorge, it chaunst a knight
When chaunst Malbecco busie be elsewhere,
Of fayned loue, they chaunst to ouertake
It chaunst Sir Satyrane his steed at last,
Vpon his heauie eye-lids chaunst to fall,
So as they coursed here and there, it chaunst
The wicked stroke vpon her helmet chaunst,
And if it chaunst, (as needs it must in fight)
His doole he made, there chaunst a turtle Doue
He chaunst to come where those two Ladies late,
Him chaunst; in stead of his ï¿½mylia faire
Him for to aide, if aide he chaunst to neede,
He chaunst to meet a Dwarfe in hasty course;
He chaunst to come, whereas two comely Squires,
She chaunst vnwares to light vppon this coffer,
He chaunst to come, where happily he spide
And all the ill, which chaunst to me of late,
She chaunst to meete toward th'euen-tide
So trauelling, he chaunst far off to heed
At length it chaunst, that both their hands on hie,
I chaunst to meete this knight, who there lyes slaine,
I will the truth discouer, as it chaunst whylere.
We chaunst to come foreby a couert glade
He chaunst to come whereas a iolly Knight,
He chaunst to spie a faire and stately place,
He chaunst far off an armed Knight to spy,
Well then him chaunst his heauy armes to want,
It chaunst some furniture about her steed
He chaunst to spy a sort of shepheard groomes,
He chaunst to come, far from all peoples troad,
Through which if any grace chaunst to arize
There chaunst to them a dangerous accident;
It chaunst a sort of merchants, which were wount
He chaunst one comming towards him to spy,
They chaunst, vpon an hill not farre away,
Chaunst to espy vpon her yuory chest
Do chaunt sweet musick, to delight his mind:
The whiles some one did chaunt this louely lay;
Chaunted alowd their chearefull harmonie:
And chearefull Chaunticlere with his note shrill
Vpon a rauenous wolfe, and still did chaw
That all the poison ran about his chaw;
Long thus he chawd the cud of inward griefe,
She chaw'd the cud of louers carefull plight;
Earst chawd thereon, yet was not all so dead,
But inwardly he chawed his owne maw
And chawing vengeance all the way I went,
Chawing the cud of griefe and inward paine,
Or breake the chayne of strong necessitee,
And Furors chayne vnbinds
In bands of loue, and in sad thraldomes chayne;
All deckt with crownes, & chaynes, and girlands gay,
And there in chaynes her cruelly did bind,
And all the while salt teares bedeawd the hearers cheaks.
That cheard his friends, and did his foes amate:
Her chearefull words much cheard the feeble spright
Her selfe she set, and comfortably cheard;
She much was cheard to heare him mentiond,
But that faire Lady would be cheard for nought,
With chaunge of cheare the seeming simple maid
The diuelish hag by chaunges of my cheare
At last she vp gan lift: with trembling cheare
But yet his Lady did so well him cheare,
But be of cheare, and comfort to you take:
And with sweet ioyous cheare him thus bespake;
With hartie words her knight she gan to cheare,
Whose sight my feeble soule doth greatly cheare:
Who forth proceeding with sad sober cheare,
And fained cheare, as for the time behoues,
One thought their cheare too litle, th'other thought too mutch.
Can chaunge my cheare, or make me euer mourne;
Her selfe to cherish, and her guest to cheare:
Faire Damzell, seemeth, by your troubled cheare,
Her bountie she abated, and his cheare empayrd.
Chaunged thy liuely cheare, and liuing made thee dead?
And fain'd to cheare his Ladie in dismay;
That cheareful word his weake hart much did cheare,
The morrow next appeard with ioyous cheare,
And next to Cambell, whose sad ruefull cheare
Shew'd change of better cheare: so sore a breach
Then for to rue the others heauy cheare;
And heauens laugh, & all the world shews ioyous cheare.
And askt him where, and when her bridale cheare
Timely to ioy, and carrie comely cheare.
For he their host them goodly well did cheare,
That by your change of cheare is easie for to see.
For the proud Souldan with presumpteous cheare,
And her gan cheare, with what she there had vewed,
He did him selfe encourage, and take better cheare.
But hanging downe her head with heauie cheare,
Wayting his foe, it did her dead hart cheare,
Great cheare, like one vnto a banquet bid;
Temper his griefe, and turned it to cheare,
To cheare his guests, whom he had stayd that night,
And afterwards to cheare with speaches kind.
Nor better cheare to shew in misery,
With gladfull speaches, and with louely cheare,
And cheared well with wine and spiceree:
And hauing cheared her, thus said; faire Dame,
That cheareful word his weake hart much did cheare,
Remounted vp as light as chearefull Larke,
And chearefull Chaunticlere with his note shrill
My chearefull day is turnd to chearelesse night,
His chearefull whistle merrily doth sound,
That Phoebus chearefull face durst neuer vew,
And chearefull bloud in faintnesse chill did melt,
His chearefull words reuiu'd her chearelesse spright,
Since I the heauens chearefull face did vew,
Farre from that haunt all other chearefull fowle;
Not all so chearefull seemed she of sight,
And entertaines with friendly chearefull mood.
With chearefull vew; who when to her they came,
Did paint his chearefull cheekes, yet being ded,
Chaunted alowd their chearefull harmonie:
The hew thereof: for vew of chearefull day
And heauens chearefull face enueloped,
The ioyous birdes shrouded in chearefull shade,
Her chearefull words much cheard the feeble spright
Hee turnd againe, and chearefull looks as earst did shew.
Which, chearefull signe did send vnto her sight,
Of chearefull looke and louely to behold;
She chearefull fresh and full of ioyance glad,
Nathlesse he hardly of her chearefull speech
That in short space his wonted chearefull hew
Yet chearefull signes he shewed outwardly.
A chearefull countenance on them let fall,
With such his chearefull speaches he doth wield
His chearefull face, and light to men restore,
But rather did more chearefull seeme therefore.
Gan reare her eyes as to the chearefull light,
Vprear'd her head to see that chearefull sight.
Had neuer ioyance felt, nor chearefull thought,
All which together sung full chearefully
My chearefull day is turnd to chearelesse night,
His chearefull words reuiu'd her chearelesse spright,
The chearelesse man, whom sorrow did dismay,
From heauen high to chase the chearelesse darke,
Tho when as chearelesse Night ycouered had
And chearelesse hunger, they together spent;
She cast to bring him, where he chearen might,
